column2: Well, Mr. Goodwood, I should hope so! Henrietta returned imperturbably.
column3: Well, mr Goodwood, I should hope so! Henrietta returned imperturbably.

column2: CHAPTER XLV
column3: CHAPTER forty five

column2: I have already had reason to say that Isabel knew her husband to be displeased by the continuance of Ralph's visit to Rome.
column3: I have already had reason to say that Isabel knew her husband to be displeased by the continuance of Ralph's visit to Rome.

column2: That knowledge was very present to her as she went to her cousin's hotel the day after she had invited Lord Warburton to give a tangible proof of his sincerity; and at this moment, as at others, she had a sufficient perception of the sources of Osmond's opposition.
column3: That knowledge was very present to her as she went to her cousin's hotel the day after she had invited Lord Warburton to give a tangible proof of his sincerity; and at this moment, as at others, she had a sufficient perception of the sources of Osmond's opposition.

column2: He wished her to have no freedom of mind, and he knew perfectly well that Ralph was an apostle of freedom.

column3: It weighed upon her imagination, however; constantly present to her mind were all the traditionary decencies and sanctities of marriage.

column2: The idea of violating them filled her with shame as well as with dread, for on giving herself away she had lost sight of this contingency in the perfect belief that her husband's intentions were as generous as her own.

column3: The prospect made her heart beat and her cheeks burn, as I say, in advance; there were moments when, in her wish to avoid an open rupture, she found herself wishing Ralph would start even at a risk.

column2: And it was of no use that, when catching herself in this state of mind, she called herself a feeble spirit, a coward. It was not that she loved Ralph less, but that almost anything seemed preferable to repudiating the most serious act--the single sacred act--of her life.

column2: That appeared to make the whole future hideous. To break with Osmond once would be to break for ever; any open acknowledgement of irreconcilable needs would be an admission that their whole attempt had proved a failure.

column2: Pansy was already dressed; she was always in advance of the time: it seemed to illustrate her pretty patience and the graceful stillness with which she could sit and wait. At present she was seated, in her fresh array, before the bed-room fire; she had blown out her candles on the completion of her toilet, in accordance with the economical habits in which she had been brought up sand which she was now more careful than ever to observe; so that the room was lighted only by a couple of logs.
column3: Pansy was already dressed; she was always in advance of the time: it seemed to illustrate her pretty patience and the graceful stillness with which she could sit and wait. column2: The rooms in Palazzo Roccanera were as spacious as they were numerous, and Pansy's virginal bower was an immense chamber with a dark, heavily-timbered ceiling. Its diminutive mistress, in the midst of it, appeared but a speck of humanity, and as she got up, with quick deference, to welcome Isabel, the latter was more than ever struck with her shy sincerity.
column3: The rooms in Palazzo Roccanera were as spacious as they were numerous, and Pansy's virginal bower was an immense chamber with a dark, heavily timbered ceiling. Its diminutive mistress, in the midst of it, appeared but a speck of humanity, and as she got up, with quick deference, to welcome Isabel, the latter was more than ever struck with her shy sincerity.

column3: Put Pansy seemed to have guessed she had come more or less as a confessor; for after she had moved the chair in which she had been sitting a little nearer to the fire and Isabel had taken her place in it, she kneeled down on a cushion in front of her, looking up and resting her clasped hands on her stepmother's knees.

column3: What Isabel wished to do was to hear from her own lips that her mind was not occupied with Lord Warburton; but if she desired the assurance she felt herself by no means at liberty to provoke it.

column2: It was difficult to interrogate without appearing to suggest; Pansy's supreme simplicity, an innocence even more complete than Isabel had yet judged it, gave to the most tentative enquiry something of the effect of an admonition.

column2: As she knelt there in the vague firelight, with her pretty dress dimly shining, her hands folded half in appeal and half in submission, her soft eyes, raised and fixed, full of the seriousness of the situation, she looked to Isabel like a childish martyr decked out for sacrifice and scarcely presuming even to hope to avert it.
column3: As she knelt there in the vague firelight, with her pretty dress dimly shining, her hands folded half in appeal and half in submission, her soft eyes, raised and fixed, full of the seriousness of the situation, she looked to Isabel like a childish martyr decked out for sacrifice and scarcely presuming even to hope to avert it.

column2: When Isabel said to her that she had never yet spoken to her of what might have been going on in relation to her getting married, but that her silence had not been indifference or ignorance, had only been the desire to leave her at liberty, Pansy bent forward, raised her face nearer and nearer, and with a little murmur which evidently expressed a deep longing, answered that she had greatly wished her to speak and that she begged her to advise her now.
column3: When Isabel said to her that she had never yet spoken to her of what might have been going on in relation to her getting married, but that her silence had not been indifference or ignorance, had only been the desire to leave her at liberty, Pansy bent forward, raised her face nearer and nearer, and with a little murmur which evidently expressed a deep longing, answered that she had greatly wished her to speak and that she begged her to advise her now.

column2: It's difficult for me to advise you, Isabel returned.
column3: It's difficult for me to advise you, Isabel returned.

column2: I don't know how I can undertake that.	I don't know how I can undertake that.
column3: true

column2: That's for your father; you must get his advice and, above all, you must act on it."
column3: That's for your father; you must get his advice and, above all, you must act on it."

column2: At this Pansy dropped her eyes; for a moment she said nothing.
column3: At this Pansy dropped her eyes; for a moment she said nothing.

column2: I think I should like your advice better than papa's, she presently remarked.
column3: I think I should like your advice better than papa's, she presently remarked.

column2: That's not as it should be, said Isabel coldly.
column3: That's not as it should be, said Isabel coldly.

column2: I love you very much, but your father loves you better.
column3: I love you very much, but your father loves you better.

column2: It isn't because you love me--it's because you're a lady, Pansy answered with the air of saying something very reasonable.
column3: It isn't because you love me-it's because you're a lady, Pansy answered with the air of saying something very reasonable.

column2: A lady can advise a young girl better than a man.
column3: A lady can advise a young girl better than a man.

column2: I advise you then to pay the greatest respect to your father's wishes.
column3: I advise you then to pay the greatest respect to your father's wishes.

column2: Ah yes, said the child eagerly, "I must do that."
column3: Ah yes, said the child eagerly, "I must do that."

column2: But if I speak to you now about your getting married it's not for your own sake, it's for mine, Isabel went on.
column3: But if I speak to you now about your getting married it's not for your own sake, it's for mine, Isabel went on.

column2: If I try to learn from you what you expect, what you desire, it's only that I may act accordingly.
column3: If I try to learn from you what you expect, what you desire, it's only that I may act accordingly.

column2: Pansy stared, and then very quickly, "Will you do everything I want?" she asked.
column3: Pansy stared, and then very quickly, "Will you do everything I want?" she asked.

column2: Before I say yes I must know what such things are.
column3: Before I say yes I must know what such things are.

column2: Pansy presently told her that the only thing she wanted in life was to marry Mr. Rosier.
column3: Pansy presently told her that the only thing she wanted in life was to marry mr Rosier.

column2: He had asked her and she had told him she would do so if her papa would allow it.
column3: He had asked her and she had told him she would do so if her papa would allow it.

column2: Now her papa wouldn't allow it.
column3: Now her papa wouldn't allow it.

column2: Very well then, it's impossible, Isabel pronounced.
column3: Very well then, it's impossible, Isabel pronounced.

column2: Yes, it's impossible, said Pansy without a sigh and with the same extreme attention in her clear little face.
column3: Yes, it's impossible, said Pansy without a sigh and with the same extreme attention in her clear little face.

column2: You must think of something else then, Isabel went on; but Pansy, sighing at this, told her that she had attempted that feat without the least success.
column3: You must think of something else then, Isabel went on; but Pansy, sighing at this, told her that she had attempted that feat without the least success.

column2: You think of those who think of you, she said with a faint smile.
column3: You think of those who think of you, she said with a faint smile.

column2: I know Mr. Rosier thinks of me.
column3: I know mr Rosier thinks of me.

column2: He ought not to, said Isabel loftily.
column3: He ought not to, said Isabel loftily.

column2: Your father has expressly requested he shouldn't.
column3: Your father has expressly requested he shouldn't.

column2: He can't help it, because he knows I think of HIM.
column3: He can't help it, because he knows I think of HIM.

column2: You shouldn't think of him.	You shouldn't think of him.
column3: true

column2: There's some excuse for him, perhaps; but there's none for you."
column3: There's some excuse for him, perhaps; but there's none for you."

column2: I wish you would try to find one, the girl exclaimed as if she were praying to the Madonna.
column3: I wish you would try to find one, the girl exclaimed as if she were praying to the Madonna.

column2: I should be very sorry to attempt it, said the Madonna with unusual frigidity.
column3: I should be very sorry to attempt it, said the Madonna with unusual frigidity.

column2: If you knew some one else was thinking of you, would you think of him?
column3: If you knew some one else was thinking of you, would you think of him?

column2: No one can think of me as Mr. Rosier does; no one has the right.
column3: No one can think of me as mr Rosier does; no one has the right.

column2: Ah, but I don't admit Mr. Rosier's right! Isabel hypocritically cried.
column3: Ah, but I don't admit mr Rosier's right! Isabel hypocritically cried.

column2: Pansy only gazed at her, evidently much puzzled; and Isabel, taking advantage of it, began to represent to her the wretched consequences of disobeying her father.
column3: Pansy only gazed at her, evidently much puzzled; and Isabel, taking advantage of it, began to represent to her the wretched consequences of disobeying her father.

column2: At this Pansy stopped her with the assurance that she would never disobey him, would never marry without his consent.
column3: At this Pansy stopped her with the assurance that she would never disobey him, would never marry without his consent.

column2: And she announced, in the serenest, simplest tone, that, though she might never marry Mr. Rosier, she would never cease to think of him.
column3: And she announced, in the serenest, simplest tone, that, though she might never marry mr Rosier, she would never cease to think of him.

column2: She appeared to have accepted the idea of eternal singleness; but Isabel of course was free to reflect that she had no conception of its meaning. She was perfectly sincere; she was prepared to give up her lover.
column3: She appeared to have accepted the idea of eternal singleness; but Isabel of course was free to reflect that she had no conception of its meaning. She was perfectly sincere; she was prepared to give up her lover.

column2: This might seem an important step toward taking another, but for Pansy, evidently, it failed to lead in that direction.
column3: This might seem an important step toward taking another, but for Pansy, evidently, it failed to lead in that direction.

column2: She felt no bitterness toward her father; there was no bitterness in her heart; there was only the sweetness of fidelity to Edward Rosier, and a strange, exquisite intimation that she could prove it better by remaining single than even by marrying him.
column3: She felt no bitterness toward her father; there was no bitterness in her heart; there was only the sweetness of fidelity to Edward Rosier, and a strange, exquisite intimation that she could prove it better by remaining single than even by marrying him.

column2: Your father would like you to make a better marriage, said Isabel. "Mr.
column3: Your father would like you to make a better marriage, said Isabel. "mr

column2: Rosier's fortune is not at all large."
column3: Rosier's fortune is not at all large."

column2: How do you mean better--if that would be good enough?	How do you mean better-if that would be good enough?

column2: And I have myself so little money; why should I look for a fortune?"
column3: And I have myself so little money; why should I look for a fortune?"

column2: Your having so little is a reason for looking for more. With which Isabel was grateful for the dimness of the room; she felt as if her face were hideously insincere.
column3: Your having so little is a reason for looking for more. With which Isabel was grateful for the dimness of the room; she felt as if her face were hideously insincere.

column2: It was what she was doing for Osmond; it was what one had to do for Osmond!
column3: It was what she was doing for Osmond; it was what one had to do for Osmond!

column2: Pansy's solemn eyes, fixed on her own, almost embarrassed her; she was ashamed to think she had made so light of the girl's preference.
column3: Pansy's solemn eyes, fixed on her own, almost embarrassed her; she was ashamed to think she had made so light of the girl's preference.

column2: What should you like me to do? her companion softly demanded.
column3: What should you like me to do? her companion softly demanded.

column2: The question was a terrible one, and Isabel took refuge in timorous vagueness.
column3: The question was a terrible one, and Isabel took refuge in timorous vagueness.

column2: To remember all the pleasure it's in your power to give your father.
column3: To remember all the pleasure it's in your power to give your father.

column2: To marry some one else, you mean--if he should ask me?
column3: To marry some one else, you mean-if he should ask me?

column2: For a moment Isabel's answer caused itself to be waited for; then she heard herself utter it in the stillness that Pansy's attention seemed to make.
column3: For a moment Isabel's answer caused itself to be waited for; then she heard herself utter it in the stillness that Pansy's attention seemed to make.

column2: Yes--to marry some one else.
column3: Yes-to marry some one else.

column2: The child's eyes grew more penetrating; Isabel believed she was doubting her sincerity, and the impression took force from her slowly getting up from her cushion.
column3: The child's eyes grew more penetrating; Isabel believed she was doubting her sincerity, and the impression took force from her slowly getting up from her cushion.

column2: She stood there a moment with her small hands unclasped and then quavered out: "Well, I hope no one will ask me!"
column3: She stood there a moment with her small hands unclasped and then quavered out: "Well, I hope no one will ask me!"

column2: There has been a question of that.	There has been a question of that.

column2: Some one else would have been ready to ask you."
column3: Some one else would have been ready to ask you."

column2: I don't think he can have been ready, said Pansy.
column3: I don't think he can have been ready, said Pansy.

column2: It would appear so if he had been sure he'd succeed.
column3: It would appear so if he had been sure he'd succeed.

column2: If he had been sure?	If he had been sure?
column3: true

column2: Then he wasn't ready!"
column3: Then he wasn't ready!"

column2: Isabel thought this rather sharp; she also got up and stood a moment looking into the fire.
column3: Isabel thought this rather sharp; she also got up and stood a moment looking into the fire.

column2: Lord Warburton has shown you great attention, she resumed; "of course you know it's of him I speak." She found herself, against her expectation, almost placed in the position of justifying herself; which led her to introduce this nobleman more crudely than she had intended.

column2: He has been very kind to me, and I like him very much.	He has been very kind to me, and I like him very much.

column2: But if you mean that he'll propose for me I think you're mistaken."
column3: But if you mean that he'll propose for me I think you're mistaken."

column2: Perhaps I am.	Perhaps I am.

column2: But your father would like it extremely."
column3: But your father would like it extremely."

column2: Pansy shook her head with a little wise smile.
column3: Pansy shook her head with a little wise smile.

column2: Lord Warburton won't propose simply to please papa.
column3: Lord Warburton won't propose simply to please papa.

column2: Your father would like you to encourage him, Isabel went on mechanically.
column3: Your father would like you to encourage him, Isabel went on mechanically.

column2: How can I encourage him?
column3: How can I encourage him?

column2: I don't know.	I don't know.

column2: Your father must tell you that."
column3: Your father must tell you that."

column2: Pansy said nothing for a moment; she only continued to smile as if she were in possession of a bright assurance.
column3: Pansy said nothing for a moment; she only continued to smile as if she were in possession of a bright assurance.

column2: There's no danger--no danger! she declared at last.
column3: There's no danger-no danger! she declared at last.

column2: There was a conviction in the way she said this, and a felicity in her believing it, which conduced to Isabel's awkwardness.
column3: There was a conviction in the way she said this, and a felicity in her believing it, which conduced to Isabel's awkwardness.

column2: She felt accused of dishonesty, and the idea was disgusting.

column2: To repair her self-respect she was on the point of saying that Lord Warburton had let her know that there was a danger.
column3: To repair her self respect she was on the point of saying that Lord Warburton had let her know that there was a danger.

column2: But she didn't; she only said--in her embarrassment rather wide of the mark--that he surely had been most kind, most friendly.
column3: But she didn't; she only said-in her embarrassment rather wide of the mark-that he surely had been most kind, most friendly.

column2: Yes, he has been very kind, Pansy answered.
column3: Yes, he has been very kind, Pansy answered.

column2: That's the meaning of his kindness.

column2: You oughtn't to let him have false hopes.

column2: It relieved this friend of a heavy responsibility. Pansy had a sufficient illumination of her own, and Isabel felt that she herself just now had no light to spare from her small stock. Nevertheless it still clung to her that she must be loyal to Osmond, that she was on her honour in dealing with his daughter.

column2: CHAPTER XLVI

column2: Lord Warburton was not seen in Mrs. Osmond's drawing-room for several days, and Isabel couldn't fail to observe that her husband said nothing to her about having received a letter from him.
column3: Lord Warburton was not seen in mrs Osmond's drawing room for several days, and Isabel couldn't fail to observe that her husband said nothing to her about having received a letter from him.

column2: She couldn't fail to observe, either, that Osmond was in a state of expectancy and that, though it was not agreeable to him to betray it, he thought their distinguished friend kept him waiting quite too long.
column3: She couldn't fail to observe, either, that Osmond was in a state of expectancy and that, though it was not agreeable to him to betray it, he thought their distinguished friend kept him waiting quite too long.

column2: At the end of four days he alluded to his absence.
